 INTRODUCTION

The Clean Air Act (CAA) required the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to promulgate regulations to prevent accidental releases of regulated toxic and flammable substances and reduce the severity of those releases that may occur.  Subsequently, EPA promulgated regulations that apply to all stationary sources with processes that contain more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance.  This regulation "Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions" (part 68 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR)) is intended to prevent accidental releases of substance that can cause serious harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposure and to mitigate the severity of releases that may occur.

In general, part 68 requires that if a facility stores or handles the regulated toxic or flammable substances is excess of the threshold quantities listed in the regulation that:
¿	Covered facilities must develop and implement a risk management program (RMP program) and maintain documentation of the program at the site.  The RMP program will include an analysis of the potential off-site consequences of an accidental release, a five-year accident history, a release prevention program, and an emergency response plan.
¿	Covered facilities also must develop and submit their initial risk management plan (RMP plan), which includes registration information, to the EPA no later than June 21, 1999.  The RMP plan provides a summary of the RMP program.  The RMP plan will be available to federal, state, and local government agencies and the public.
¿	Covered facilities also must continue to implement the RMP program and update the RMP plan periodically or when the processes change.

The phrase "risk management program" (RMP program) refers to all the requirements of the RMP regulations, which must be implemented on an ong

oing basis.  The phrase "risk management plan" (RMP plan) refers to the document summarizing the RMP program that is submitted to EPA.  The RMP regulations define the acronym RMP as the RMP plan.  However, to avoid confusion and for clarity, "RMP plan" will be used in this document.
The Greensboro Olympic Products location falls under a Program 2 category.  
The RMP regulations require that the RMP program for covered facilities include the following:
¿	Hazard Assessment
¿	Prevention Program
¿	Emergency Response Program
¿	RMP plan submittal

The following sections briefly describe each of these requirements.  

HAZARD ASSESSMENT
All facilities must assess the following:
¿	One worst-case release scenario representing all toxic substances held at the facility in excess of threshold quantities.
¿	And one worst-case release scenario representing all regulated flammable substances held at the facility in excess of threshold quantities.  
¿	Program 2 facilities must also assess at least one alternative release scenario for each regulated toxic substance and one alternative scenario representing all flammable substances held at the facility in excess of the threshold quantities. 
 
The assessment includes dispersion modeling, identification of the area where off-site impacts are in excess of specified toxic or fire/explosion "end-point" criteria and estimating the potentially affected public and environmental receptors.  The assessment also includes a 5-year accident history involving releases of regulated substances.
EPA had defined a worst-case release as the release as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance that results in the greatest distance from the point of release to a specified endpoint.  Passive mitigation (e.g. berms, dikes, drains) can be included in determining the distance to the specified endpoint.

 

The RMP regulations specify many of the parameters to be used to estimate these distances, including meteorology, release height, liqui

d temperatures, etc. The alternative release scenarios selected should be more likely to occur than the worst-case.  They may be based on the accident history or process hazard analysis. While not explicitly stated, the intent is to select a credible alternative release scenario that provides a basis for planning on-site emergency response and off-site community response.

5-YEAR ACCIDENT SUMMARY
The 5-year accident history includes incidents from covered processes that resulted in on-site or off-site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

There have been no such incidents that met the criteria above.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Olympic Products, LLC believes the health and safety of its employees and the protection of the natural environment, should be of the utmost concern in the operation of its business. We are committed to operating and maintaining all processes in a safe and responsible manner.

It is the policy to:
¿	Comply with all applicable laws, regulations and standards.
¿	Review and assess operations for making health, safety & environmental improvements.  

Our complete Health, Safety & Environmental policy statement, signed by our Plant Manager, is posted in the lobby of our facility.  We use a combination of prevention programs and emergency response planning, which are described late in this document, to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protect the environment. Our Plant Manager has the overall responsibility for ensuring our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner. This responsibility includes overseeing the implementation of the elements of our risk management program. To ensure that our risk management program is appropriately developed and implemented, our Plant Manager has assigned the role of RMP coordinator to a staff member with the background, training, and the experience necessary to manage the program. The RMP Co

ordinator, acting with the authority delegated directly from the Plant Manager, is responsible for coordinating the development, implementation and integration of the RMP elements as is required under Section 68.15 of the RMP rule.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of chemicals. Our management systems for our TDI processes address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:
¿	Safety information.
¿	Hazard reviews of our processes.
¿	Operator procedures for transferring and storing TDI.
¿	Controls are in place to reduce the hazards of Isocyanate exposure to the employees, the    
¿	community and the environment.
¿	Process controls also exist to minimize potential releases (e.g. tank level gauges, high level alarms, high-pressure switches, rupture disks, and system interlocks).

These listed individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we conduct business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.

MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
The RMP regulation explicitly requires a documented Management Program with a clear delineation of overall management responsibility for the RMP program and lines of authority for all personnel assigned responsibility for individual RMP program elements. Roles and responsibilities are laid out in Table 4.1.

PREVENTION PROGRAM
EPA's Program 2 prevention program was designed for relatively simple processes at facilities outside the petrochemical industry that are not subject to OSHA's PSM regulations.  Program 2 requirements include simplified version of six of the 12 Program 3 elements.  These include:  hazard review; operating procedures; training; maintenance; comp

liance audits; and incident investigation.

Olympic's implementation of the Program 2 requirements is discussed in section 8 of this document.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Both the EPA RMP and OSHA PSM regulations rely mainly on previous requirements for emergency action plans and training (29 CFR 1910.38{a} and 1910.120 {a},{p}, and {q}). The RMP regulation continues to allow a facility to evacuate and not actively respond to accidental releases, provided that the facility is included in the community emergency response plan developed under United States Code (U.S.C.) 11003 and that appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders.  While the RMP regulation allows the use of plans and programs developed under prior emergency response regulations, it stipulates that the plan include items required under the statute, notably procedures for informing the public and local responders about a release.
We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning. Our program provides essential planning and training for effective protecting workers, the public and the environment during emergency situations. 

We have coordinated our program with local emergency planning committee and the fire department. The LEPC, SERC, and local fire department have copies of an SDS for TDI and have copies of facility maps which identifies TDI unloading, storage, and handling areas. A representative of the fire department routinely visits the plants to discuss emergency response procedures.

The core elements of the emergency response plan identify detailed procedures and protocols to be initiated in the event of a release. The following responses are addressed in our plan:
¿	Proper notifications in the event of a release (internal and external).
¿	Systematic shutdown of operations.
¿	Evacuation of personnel.
¿	First aid procedures.
¿	Emergency response team actions.
¿	Decontam

ination of personnel and equipment.
¿	Management of waste material.
¿	Startup of operations.
¿	Accident/Incident investigations.

The site maintains an active Emergency Response Team (ERT). The unit conducts quarterly spill drills that are both hands on as well as table top exercises.

¿	Within six months of a change that requires a revised offsite consequence analysis.

APPLICABILITY
The facility has inventoried all chemicals stored or handled at the facility and determined that only TDI is subject to the RMP regulations.  To accomplish this task the maximum inventory of TDI onsite was compared to the threshold quantities listed in the RMP regulations.  Upon review of the facility operations, it was determined that the entire facility is considered one process.  It was also determined that the facility would be subject to Program 2 of the RMP regulations.  Table 2-1 illustrates the comparison of the maximum amount stored on-site to the threshold quantity.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED.
The Olympic Products facility's primary purpose is to produce polyurethane foam for the automotive and furniture industries. Polyurethane foam is manufactured by combining specific ratios of chemical streams in a mixing chamber where the reacting ingredients are dispensed onto a moving conveyor system. The reacting mixture cures into the form of a slabstock "bun." The foam buns are fabricated into rolled and flat goods. Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI), which is regulated by EPA's risk management rule, is one of the reagents required to manufacture polyurethane foam. TDI is received at the plant by railcar and tanker truck; it is stored in four tanks located in the contained bulk storage tank room.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, management personnel, and contractors. The maximum amount of TDI that can stored at this facility is 680,000 pounds.

3.0 GENERAL DUTY
Section 112 (r)(l) of the CAA requires that "owners and operators of stationary sources producing, processing, handling, or storing...(substances regulated by this rule) or any other extremely hazardous substance, have a general duty to identify hazards which may result from... releases using appropriate assessment techniques, to design and maintain a safe facility taking such measures as are necessary to prevent releases and to minimize the consequences of accidental releases which do occur."  In accordance with Section 112 (r)(l) of the CAA, the facility is committed to designing and maintaining a safe facility.  The facility will take steps as are necessary to prevent the accidental release and minimizing the consequences of any such release of any regulated substances defined in 29 CFR, Part 68 or any other extremely hazardous substance.

OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
The RMP regulations require an off-site consequence analysis be conducted to evaluate the impacts of potential accidental releases of regulated substances on public health and the environment.  EPA has developed an RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance document (EPA 1999), which provides simple calculations and "look-up" tables that are based on conservative release estimates as well as simple dispersion modeling methods.  This guidance document or more refined publicly available techniques can be used to estimate the consequence distances (or distance to "endpoint") of the worst-case and alternative release scenarios.

For toxic substances the "endpoint" is based on:
¿	The Emergency Response Planning Guidance, Level 2 (ERPG), which protects individuals from health - threatening or escape-impairing injury; or if the ERPG does not exist.
¿	The Level of Concern (LOC) from SARA Title III Guidance, generally defined as the Immediately Dangerous to Life or Health (IDLH) level divided by a safety factor of 10.

The facility previously utilized the Area Location of Hazardous Atmospheres (ALOHA) model to estimate the release rates and the distance to toxic endpoints for TDI.  The ALOHA model was originally developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (distributed by the National Safety Council) as an emergency response model.  Many LEPCs have traditionally used ALOHA for planning purposes.  However, for the most recent submittal and analysis, RMP*Comp™ was used to complete the Off-site Consequence Analyses. The results from the use of this program v. ALHOA are different. However, each are acceptable under the requirements of RMP. 





WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO ANALYSIS
The RMP program regulations define a w

orst-case release as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance that results in the greatest distance from the point of release to a specified endpoint.  Passive mitigation (e.g. berms, dikes, drains, etc.) can be included in determining the distance to the specified endpoint.   The RMP plan must contain one worst-case release scenario that results in the greatest distance to the endpoint to represent all flammable substances on-site.  Additional worst-case release scenarios may need to be evaluated if the release of a different toxic substance or flammable would have impacts on public receptors different from those defined above.  The RMP regulations specifically define how to determine the worst-case release scenarios.  The worst-case release scenario selected for evaluation for TDI handled at the facility is the release of a 20,000 gallon railcar.  The railcar is located outside.

The RMP regulations specify the meteorological and other modeling parameters that must be used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenarios.  Table 5-1 summarizes these parameters.  The facility used the ALOHA model and guidance contained in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance document to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint for each worst-case release scenario.  For the worst-case scenario, the maximum temperature in the past three years at the Greensboro, NC meteorological station of 100 ˚F was used (2004).

The results showed a distance of  0.07 miles (1.1 kilometers) to the toxic endpoint for TDI.  There would be approximately 1,200 people impacted from the modeled railcar. The impact would be to schools, residences and recreational areas. This was determined by the Offsite Consequence Analysis-Worst Case Scenario, modeled by Golder Associates (see Risk Management Plan Submittal for The TDI System Sept 2014-093-9676014).  There would be no environmental receptors within the ring of the modeled railcar.

ALOHA model printouts are included.



ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO ANALYSIS
The RMP regulations require an alternative release scenario evaluation for each regulated toxic substance and at least one alternative release scenario evaluation to represent all flammable substances is included in the RMP plan.  Passive and active mitigation measures (e.g. shutoff valves, alarms, etc) can be included in the alternative release analysis.  The scenario chosen for inclusion in the RMP plan the five-year accident history and the process hazard analysis conducted under the Prevention Program of the RMP program was a break in a 2" flexible hose used to transfer the 65/35 TDI from the delivery truck to the tank

This equipment is located outside of the tank building. However, the liquid would flow into a containment dike. The spill would, therefore, be contained - the effect of the containment dike was included in the analysis. The estimated flow is 500 lbs/min. Due to the requirements that the offloading be manned at all times, the duration of the spill would not exceed a period of five minutes. Using RMP Comp, the initial transfer rate and other process parameters, as well as the five-minute release period, the estimated spill amount would be 27,550 lbs of TDI. As with the worst-case scenario release, the evaporation rate of TDI from the spilled pool of liquid was reported as a released rate to the air. Again, using RMP Comp, Golder determined the mitigated alternative release rate to be 0.16 lbs/min.  

5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The facility has not had any accidental releases from the covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

update the facilities Program 2 Prevention Program.  Additional information and/or specific documentation (when feasible) for each Prevention Program element is provided.

Any issues identified during the hazard review were documented and will be resolved in a timely manner.  The hazard review will be revalidated and updated once every five years following completion of the initial ha

zard review.  A hazard assessment has been performed for these areas:

¿	TDI controls, safeguards, and interlocks.
¿	TDI hoses.
¿	TDI metering pumps.
¿	TDI tanker truck

¿	Identification of hazards associated with the process and regulated substances.

TRAINING
New employees working with a covered process receive initial training in accordance with 40 CFR 68.54.  The training includes an overview of the process and emphasizes the process operating procedures, safe work practices, health and safety hazards, and emergency operations including shutdown.   

Refresher training is provided at a minimum of every three years to all employees involved in working with a covered process.  Training can occur more frequent if requested by the employee.  Documentation is maintained for each employee to ensure that he or she received the required training. 

HAZWOPER is provided to those employees serving on the Emergency Response Team (ERT).

MAINTENANCE
A maintenance program has been developed in accordance with 40 CFR 68.56 for covered process equipment.  Employees involved in the maintenance of covered processes receive additional training, which includes an overview of the process, its hazards, how to avoid or correct unsafe conditions, and in the procedures applicable to the employee's job tasks.

Maintenance contractors are trained in the hazards of TDI prior to beginning work as laid out in the contractor orientation package-Schedules A through D.

Preven

tative Maintenance (PMs) are performed on a routine schedule and determined by manufacturer recommendations or from the requirements set forth by the corporate engineering group.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS
RMP compliance is confirmed through safety audits that are performed at least once every three years in accordance with 40 CFR 68.58.  The audits are completed by a least one person knowledgeable in the process.  A report of the findings is generated following the audit, and all deficiencies and/or recommendations are promptly addressed and the resolution is documented.  The two most recent audit reports are maintained at the facility.

INCIDENT INVESTIGTATION
Specific incident investigation, reporting, and documentation procedures have been implemented and are followed in accordance with 40 CFR 68.60 in response to any incident involving a covered process that did or could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  Under EPA RMP, a catastrophic release is defined as a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion involving one or more regulated substances that present imminent and substantial endangerment to publish health and the environment.

The incident investigation procedure is initiated as soon as possible and no later that 48 hours following any incident.  A team is established to perform the incident investigation and always includes at least one person knowledgeable in the process, a contract employee if the incident involves work by a contractor, and other persons with appropriate qualifications to investigate an accident.

Following the investigation, a written report is prepared summarizing the following information at a minimum: date of the incident; date the investigation began; description of the incident and any contributing factors; and any recommendations resulting from the investigation.  When completed, all affected personnel including contract employees review the report.  Incident investigation reports are mai

ntained at the facility for a minimum of 5 years.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE
The facility has an emergency response program that includes an emergency response plan addressing RMP regulated substances present at the facility.

TDI spills will be handled by the facilities trained emergency response team.  In the case of a catastrophic release (tank rupture, railcar overturns, etc.), the facility will contact the appropriate Hazard Response Company to perform the clean up along with notifying the appropriate agencies.

Small spills where the facility employees will clean up the spill does not meet the EPA interpretation of "response".  In addition, the facility is included in the community emergency response plan and has implemented procedures for informing the appropriate agencies about any accidental releases.  Therefore, the facility is not required to have a detailed Emergency Response Plan under RMP.
